fields.description:
Generally, when you try to convert an existing issue in an *active sprint* as a sub-task and set the parent task from a newly added issue into the active sprint will result a *scope change* in the burndown chart.

h3. Steps to reproduce:
# Create a few issues with all of them set with original estimate value
# Create a scrum board
# Configure the Estimation Statistic to *Original Time Estimate* and Time Tracking to *Remaining Estimate and Time Spent* 
# Create a Sprint
# Drag all these issues into a Sprint and start the Sprint
# Note total time remaining estimate on Burndown Report
# Create a new issue *without any original estimate value* and add this new issue to the ongoing active sprint
# Select one issue from the sprint with time estimate value and convert it to a sub-task and set the parent task to the newly added issue
# View Burndown Report again
# Burndown line goes up. It says *Scope change* - issue added (the converted issue). Expected flatline, with scope change for new container but not converted issue. Total time remaining is still same as before (correct). However, previous time remaining has been revised down to exclude the converted issues, which was always in sprint. Therefore burndown line goes up, when it should be flat.
fields.summary: scope change in burndown when converting existing issue into sub-task

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
I as a Product Owner or Scrum Master want to see a report generated by Greenhopper/JIRA Agile which shows the projected completion for the current backlog items so that I can better understand what the overall project status is today.


Further thoughts:
- able to select which epics to include as "total backlog"
- calculation based on story points
- configurable average velocity (how many or which past sprints to consider for average)
- utilize average velocity to calculate projected completion
- show how many sprints until completed
- show optimistic and pessimistic line
- configurable optimistic and pessimistic calculation (percentage)


I'm doing this today in Excel based on data I'm extracting out of JIRA.
This is the most important chart for our project and helps everybody involved to better understand where we at and take actions early to influence the project for the better.

Attaching an image of the chart I'm creating in Excel at the moment.
fields.summary: Line chart for projected backlog completion with optimistic and pessimistic

fields.description:
I have a custom field which derives from *AbstractMultiCFType* and that cannot be displayed in the Issue Detail View of the Plan and Work Modes. Looking at the GH code, in the _DetailViewFieldConfigurationServiceImpl_ class, it shows that only the following classes or classes which derives from them are supported:


* GenericTextCFType
* NumberCFType
* DateCFType
* DateTimeCFType
* UserCFType
* MultiUserCFType
* MultiGroupCFType
* LabelsCFType
* SelectCFType
* MultiSelectCFType
* VersionCFType
* CascadingSelectCFType
* EpicLinkCFType

It seems that you do not support your own base classes and many custom fields do derive from the base classes. Please at least support the *AbstractMultiCFType* as the MultiSelectCFType derives directly from it.
fields.summary: As a developer, I want the Issue Detail View in the plan and work mode to support the different JIRA custom field abstract classes so that my own custom field can be displayed

fields.description:
Provide a distribution / histogram chart for the cycle / lead time data, with bin size control and moment markers.

Acceptance Criteria:

* A. Provide histrogram chart w/ left vertical axis for frequency, and horizontal axis for cycle / lead time value bins.
* B. Show frequencies of data in aggregated bins as vertical bars (all juxtaposed).
* C. Provide control over bin size, with option for "auto" (smart built-in dynamic).
* D. Provide date range slider controls to filter data (just like Control Chart).
* E. Show colour-coded vertical line / marker for Geometric Mean, per a view-control checkbox.
* F. Show a colour-coded vertical line / marker for Geometric Median, per a view-control checkbox.
* G. Show two colour-coded vertical lines / markers for Geometric Standard Deviation above & below Geometric Mean, per a view-control checkbox.
* H. Show Lognormal probability density function (PDF) curve (fitted on same left vertical axis scale), per a view-control checkbox.
* I. Show Lognormal cumulative distribution function (CDF) curve (on new right vertical axis, with 0 to 100% scale), per a view-control checkbox.
* J. In summary footer, show Sample Size ("n"), Geometric Mean, Geometric Median, Geometric Standard Deviation, Min, Max.
* K. In summary footer, show Prediction Confidence Bound, with adjustable confidence level. (E.g., 95% confident that next work item will be complete within 15 days.)

Notes:
* Cycle / lead time is reasonably modelled with Lognormal distribution (or others), not likely Normal (as also evidenced by the existing logarithmic scale on the Control Chart's vertical axis).
* The Lognormal moments are the Geometric Mean & Geometric Standard Deviation.
fields.summary: Report - Provide chart for Cycle / Lead Time Distribution

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Repro:
# Goto Rapidboard for project (which has at least two Resolved issues).
# Open Control Chart (Report tab).

Expected:
* A. Chart should show horizontal line using Geometric Mean.
* B. Summary footer data should show Geometric Mean & Geometric Standard Deviation.

Actual:
* A. Chart shows horizontal line using Arithmetic Mean.
* B. Summary footer data shows Mean (Arithmetic) & Standard Deviation (Arithmetic).

Justification:
* Cycle/Lead time is reasonably modelled with Lognormal distribution (or others), not likely Normal (as also evidenced by the existing logarithmic scale on the Control Chart's vertical axis).
* The Lognormal moments are the Geometric Mean & Geometric Standard Deviation.
fields.summary: Report - Control Chart could be using more appropriate Mean & Standard Deviation

fields.description:
After moving an issue on the board the board is refreshed by calling {{xboard/work/allData.json}}. On our production instance this takes 6 seconds. Updating the issue is relatively quick, refreshing the board data is not.

This is down to {{com.atlassian.greenhopper.service.lucene.ChangeHistorySearchHelper#findChangeLogFilter}}. Specifically, computing the cross-references from two queries, one of which may contain up to half a million issues, is very slow. I'm sure there is a quicker way, even if it's just checking the permission for each issue retrieved from the change history index.

As a workaround I am just disabling loading the days in column data in {{com.atlassian.greenhopper.web.rapid.list.RapidIssueEntryQueryServiceImpl#collectWorkModeIssues}}, which makes things passably fast.

h3. Areas of JIRA Agile Affected

* Generating JIRA Agile charts - notably Burndown, Cumulative Flow Diagram & Control Chart.
* Loading days in column for a list of issues (workaround to disable this in GHS-10520).

h3. Workaround for Work Sub-Filter

This is fixed in JIRA 6.3.1 as tracked in JRA-38883, so this workaround will only apply for previous versions of JIRA.

It's possible that on larger instances the default work sub-filter may be causing performance issues of its own. This is not related to {{com.atlassian.greenhopper.service.lucene.ChangeHistorySearchHelper}} however does present with similar symptoms. Specifically, the [work sub-filter|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AGILE/Configuring+Filters#ConfiguringFilters-AddingaSub-FilterforWorkmode] default is:

{noformat}
fixVersion in unreleasedVersions() OR fixVersion is EMPTY
{noformat}

This {{unreleasedVersions()}} JQL may be slow for larger instances that process a large number of projects, as it goes through all of them to find out which versions are relevant. This can be sped up by specifying a list of projects _that are only relevant to the JIRA Agile board being used_. For example if we wanted to only return issues for projects GHS and JRA (because they are in the board filter), we would use the following:

{noformat}
fixVersion in unreleasedVersions(GHS,JRA) OR fixVersion is EMPTY
{noformat}

Please make the above changes and verify if the boards are faster to render or not. If they are faster, it implies the {{unreleasedVersions()}} was slow to process due to the large number of projects. If it does not it would indicate that the {{com.atlassian.greenhopper.service.lucene.ChangeHistorySearchHelper}} is the cause of slowness.

It's possible that both {{unreleasedVersions()}} and {{com.atlassian.greenhopper.service.lucene.ChangeHistorySearchHelper}} are slow to process and this workaround only addresses one part of the problem.

fields.description:
Hey guys,
What is all of this whitespace for in GreenHopper Work Mode?

At any point in time Users are juggling dozens of open tasks.  And Greenhopper seems to make the scroll unnecessarily.   It seems like I could easily fit almost twice as many issues on my screen at any one time as GreenHopper displays to me. 

Because of this whitespace waste problem, I, as a user, use ToDo, Inprogress, and Done filters in JIRA on my JIRA dashboard to display my active work.  I lose drag-n-drop but the screen-density is easily worth the trade.  

Is there a reason for this wasted space that I'm missing?

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
I find that one of the most useful tools for our software development team is the Version Report chart.  Since the addition of this one chart, we're able to much more accurately forecast the completion of a release and extremely accurately communicate the effect of scope creep on our completion date.  We have been able to determine when it's necessary to add resources to a project and communicate to upper management exactly why they need to make a priority decision on all open projects due to release schedules.

However, in order to do this, we currently create our own trend lines with a sheet of paper held up to the monitor or projector.  I've attached a screenshot that explains why this is necessary.

First off, being able to annotate this graph as I've done in this screenshot would prove invaluable for project status reports as well as "lessons learned" post-project analysis.  I'm thinking GreenHopper stores as many points on the graph as is requested as well as an annotation for each.  These points are stored per version tracked in GreenHopper.

I feel like the "project start" date should show the entire progression (graph) of a project.  However, there needs to be an option for a progression line start date separate from the project start date, as the June re-specification and reallocation of developers to the project requires a new velocity trend line.  I already did this in March, and have been considering doing it again, but if I do this, the new graph loses the historical nature as annotated in the screenshot.

Another cool idea is a "scope creep trend line".  I just noticed today that even back all the way until early mid-april, our scope creep has been extremely linear.  This, combined with current (recent) velocity could possibly create a "true" completion date where the two lines I drew intersect?

One thing I didn't show on the graph was the ability to speculate on an increased velocity over your current velocity.  This could have been used after the spec redesign in late June and the addition of more developers to the project.  I'm thinking a box on the right that says "Speculate an additional X story points per week".  This would cause the velocity trend line slope to increase starting today, causing an upward kink in the velocity trend line with an adjusted final completion date.

I know this is a huge request, but I feel like this adds a significant amount of benefit to an already great feature.  These new features will hugely help us when communicating outside our group and committing to release dates.
fields.summary: As an agile user, I would like the option to change the predicted completion date based upon recent velocity

fields.description:
h3. Summary

There are issues appearing in the Sprint Report as "Removed from Sprint", which are completed, and have *not* been removed.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

Unable to reproduce this as of yet.

h3. Expected Results

The issues appear in the "Completed Issues" section of the report.

h3. Actual Results

The issues appear in the "Issues Removed From Sprint" section of the report.

h3. Notes

This behaviour appears to be occurring due to a condition where the sprint history records are missing as the sprint was added during issue creation, potentially between the dates of the sprint. Unfortunately not able to replicate to properly identify this behaviour.

h3. Workaround

# Edit the issue to remove the sprint and save it.
# Add the issue back into the sprint. It will now appear in the correct section of the Sprint Report.
(!) Note that the issue will have a * against the issue key in the Sprint Report as GreenHopper will consider it as added to the Sprint after the sprint was started.
fields.summary: Issues that are completed are showing up as "Removed from Sprint" on the Sprint Report

fields.description:
When using the {{.}} (dot) menu to access the "Operations" menu for an issue, URLs for items that don't include a querystring are corrupted.

It looks like {{&returnUrl=...}} is indiscriminately appended to the URL for an item. This logic does not consider the case when a URL does not already include a querystring.

Steps to reproduce

# Browse to the rapid board and select an issue.
# Press {{.}} to open the Operations dialog.
# Search for {{Noti}} and wait for the "Notification Helper" suggestion to display.
# Right click the suggestion and choose "Open Link in New Tab" (or equivalent for your browser)

It's expected that the URL is:
{code}/notimportant?returnUrl=...{code}
but instead it's:
{code}/notimportant&returnUrl=...{code}

Note the {{?}} versus {{&}}

While the above example is fairly unimportant, this actually affects a JIRA feature I'm working on that allows fields to be added to an issue *from* the issue.
fields.summary: Issue operations item URLs are corrupted in the "." (shortcut) menu.

fields.description:
As a scrum master or engineering manager, I would like to understand what portion of my team's velocity is new features versus other types of estimated work. 
--------

In our company, like many, we have not settled the debate on whether to estimate bugs with story points.  There are good reasons for both approaches and I'll leave it at that.

For the teams who choose to estimate bugs, it would be of great benefit to be able to configure the velocity chart to exclude bugs and other estimated issue types besides business stories in the computation of velocity.  

Better yet, the fraction of a team's time devoted to bugs is a valuable metric, and a stacked bar chart showing the component issue types of any given sprint velocity would be incredibly valuable.
fields.summary: Add ability to configure basis issues for velocity chart

fields.description:
As per the screenshot that was shared by a user:
!auto_estimate.png|thumbnail!

The explanation to this suggestion is mentioned like the following:
{quote}
You have small team (6 - 8 persons). This team has sprint, but you do not want define sprint for each person. However, you need to know how much work (in time) is planned for each person in that team. When Issues are inserted to sprint, the values in current version of fields is calculated for all persons.

It would be great to have dynamically recalculation of these values on activating quick filter OR when quick filter is activated show just 3 new fields with "Not Started, In Progress and Done" which show times only of filtered issues.
{quote}

In the long run, this will be a helpful feature for those who make use of *Estimation Statistic* of Original Time Estimate, even Story Points for that matter whereby the usage of Quick Filters is making the estimation easier to calculate and to view.
fields.summary: Time Estimate auto-calculation via Quick Filters on the Scrum Plan Mode

fields.description:
We should use a pattern similar to the Reveal text pattern from the ADG.

* When there are more Quick Filters than there is horizontal screen space (eg. the screen is not wide enough, and they will wrap), we hide the remaining ones and display a "... Show more" link as the last Quick Filter.
* Clicking "... Show more" will reveal the rest of the Quick Filters
* "... Show more" will now change to say "Show less" instead
* The default state for all users is the collapsed state
* Whether the Filters are collapsed or all shown is persistent on a user level
* Reordering the Quick Filters stays the same as it is today
* When the header is collapsed (z on the keyboard), the behaviour stays the same.
fields.summary: Quick filters should collapse into a "... Show more" reveal pattern when they will wrap to more than one line

fields.description:
As an enterprise user we don't use Fix Version's as we require a more robust solution.

Due to this we use 3 fields to track versions/branches:

|| Target Release(s) | Custom multi-select version field |
|| Integrated in Branch(es) | Custom multi-select field |
|| Verified in Branch(es) | Custom multi-select field |

While the latter two are not backed by versions, the "Target Release(s) is. We couldn't use the Fix Version/s field in JIRA for our solution because we track our fixes in branches and not in releases. (If renaming JIRA system field was possible this would be a lot easier, we would have renamed Fix Version/s and used that).

Do to setups like ours, where users track the version through a custom version field and not versions, we would like the ability to set the backing field for the "versions" tab/panel from Fix Version/s to a custom version field at a Global GreenHopper level (So new boards default to that field for versions).

fields.description:
We are using oracle database server on which encoding is set to: WE8ISO8859P1

SELECT * FROM NLS_DATABASE_PARAMETERS WHERE PARAMETER = 'NLS_CHARACTERSET';
NLS_CHARACTERSET	WE8ISO8859P1

Encoding on db cannot be changed to UTF-8 because same db is used  for other applications that will get impacted because of this change.

With default behavior of JIRA if i enter double quotes “ or ”, they get converted into question mark ?

Since db is using this char set, we want to change JIRA to support same char set, to achieve this we have made change in following places:
1. JIRA DB: using this query
update propertystring set propertyvalue = 'ISO-8859-1' where id in (select id from propertyentry where property_key='webwork.i18n.encoding');

2. JIRA start up file (setenv.sh), added following line in jvm arguments
-Dfile.encoding=ISO-8859-1

3. Tomcat's conf/server.xml added encoding
URIEncoding="ISO-8859-1"

After these changes and bouncing JIRA, i could see change reflected in my browser and could see encoding is chnaged from UTF-8 to ISSO-8859-1.. but the problem of quotes getting converted to question mark is still there.. 

can you pls look into this and let me know what should be solution for this..
fields.summary: JIRA is converting few chars to question mark "?"

fields.description:
On the first day of this new iteration, I created a new sprint, populated it with items from the backlog, and started the new sprint.  Unfortunately, I did not close the previous sprint, which had a number of issues with open subtasks.  I realize that I was supposed to close the previous sprint before opening the new sprint, but GreenHopper does not make it easy to recover from this mistake.  In trying to maintain the sprint history for each issue, I had to manually edit the sprint number for each of the stories, removing the previous sprint from the Sprint Number list.  For some lesser issues, I just did a bulk update.

I'm not sure there's much value in supporting multiple open sprints for a given RapidBoard, but if so, make it harder to mess up the iteration rituals.
fields.summary: Starting a new sprint does not close the previous sprint

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Software Server*. Using *JIRA Software Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSWCLOUD-9512].
  {panel}

When trying to complete a sprint that has unresolved sub-tasks, instead of automatically removing these issues to the backlog Greenhopper gives error:

"Sprint cannot be completed as there are incomplete subtasks in the following issue: ..."

h2. Workarounds:
There are two possible workarounds for this problem:
* Manually remove those from the sprint - https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/GH/Removing+an+Issue+from+a+Sprint
or
* Close off the subtask issue that's caught, then reopen it to put it in the next sprint
fields.summary: Unable to complete sprint because sub-task is not resolved

fields.description:
When I start a new sprint, it may include tickets that are essentially done (i.e. in a UAT stage) on the board, but not closed/resolved. In the burndown chart these have an "inc" value of 0 and don't go into the count of tickets in that sprint graph's metrics.

However, in the Velocity chart, they ARE included in the commitment count.

I believe these tickets should not be counted in the sprint's velocity commitment because they are not items that required work to be done... having these counted essentially renders the velocity chart useless when such tickets get added to a new sprint, and incomparable with the burndown charts.

Having this configurable would be useful.
fields.summary: Velocity chart includes tickets added that were already in done pile
